qas.question: Anti-aircraft defenses became better after what?
What did they use to lure German bombers away from their targets?
What kind of airfields were prepared to stand up to skilled observers?
What was the name given to these dummy airfields?

context: In general, German bombers were likely to get through to their targets without too much difficulty. It was to be some months before an effective night fighter force would be ready, and anti-aircraft defences only became adequate after the <a0_0>Blitz was over<a0_0/>, so <a1_0>ruses<a1_0/> were created to lure German bombers away from their targets. Throughout 1940, <a2_0>dummy<a2_0/> airfields were prepared, good enough to stand up to skilled observation. A number[clarification needed] of bombs fell on these diversionary ("<a3_0>Starfish<a3_0/>") targets.
